data.title: Weird '.\' in the tab, after file name
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.14.0-insider (7e2937237620501705e4a5276e76726d35a31905, 2017-06-30T05:17:53.525Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.15063
- Extensions: 

Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---
Bookmarks|ale|0.15.2
project-manager|ale|0.18.1
vscode-eslint|dba|1.2.11
vscode-great-icons|emm|2.1.9
beautify|Hoo|1.1.1
atom-keybindings|ms-|2.9.0
seti-icons|qin|0.1.3
vscode-icons|rob|7.10.1
stylelint|shi|0.26.0
--

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open folder in VS Code.
2. Open two files with the same name. One file in the root of the folder, the other in the sub-folder.

You'll see something like this: `test.txt .\`, which looks weird. And inconsistent with what is shown in the open editors section:
![vs-slash](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/9781/27722950-c7e2f77a-5d6a-11e7-9cd4-f59791481b32.png)

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: [css/scss] Go to definition for css/sass @import

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
**Feature Request**
Support go to definition on css`@imports`

```css
@import url(./otherFile.css)
```

and [sass style imports](http://sass-lang.com/guide):

```sass
@import 'otherFile.css'
```

Go to definition  on `otherFile.css`should try to open `otherFile.css` in the workspace

data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.14.0-insider (954193248183c7bb4d70c89898bc5337ce57fe98, 2017-06-29T05:07:31.424Z) - OS Version: Darwin x64 16.6.0 --- Steps to Reproduce: 1. for the html file ```html text ``` 2. Put cursor after `text` and run `emmet: wrap with abbreviation` 3. Enter `ul>li>a` as the abbreviation **Expected** ```html
  • text
``` **Actual** Extra spaces are inserted before and after text: ```html
  • text
``` Also tested on current master

data.title: Emmet Wrap with invalid abbreviation should display error to user
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.14.0-insider (954193248183c7bb4d70c89898bc5337ce57fe98, 2017-06-29T05:07:31.424Z)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 16.6.0
---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. for the html file
```html
text
```
2. Put cusor after text and run `emmet: wrap with abbreviation`
3. Enter `ul li` as the abbreviation


**expected**
message shown about invalid abbreviation.

**Actual**
Nothing happens

This error is logged in the developer console:

```
Unable to consume abbreviation node, unexpected 32 at char 3: Error: Unable to consume abbreviation node, unexpected 32 at char 3

    at consumeElement (/Applications/Visual Studio Code - Insiders.app/Contents/Resources/app/extensions/emmet/node_modules/@emmetio/abbreviation/dist/abbreviation.cjs.js:213:16)
    at parse (/Applications/Visual Studio Code - Insiders.app/Contents/Resources/app/extensions/emmet/node_modules/@emmetio/abbreviation/dist/abbreviation.cjs.js:289:16)

    at Object.expand$$1 [as expand] (/Applications/Visual Studio Code - Insiders.app/Contents/Resources/app/extensions/emmet/node_modules/@emmetio/expand-abbreviation/dist/expand.cjs.js:233:5)
    at expandAbbr (/Applications/Visual Studio Code - Insiders.app/Contents/Resources/app/extensions/emmet/out/abbreviationActions.js:161:46)

data.title: Incorrect format on paste for blank line inside js function
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.14.0-insider (954193248183c7bb4d70c89898bc5337ce57fe98, 2017-06-29T05:07:31.424Z)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 16.6.0

---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Enable format on paste
1. Copy the js code:

```js
function abc() {

}
abc
```

note that the blank line has no whitespace on it. It is empty

3. Paste the code into a blank js file


**Expected**
Retained formatting:

```js
function abc() {

}
abc
```

**Actual**
Code is indented

```js
function abc() {
  
  }
  abc
```

data.title: [css] color suggestions are duplicated
data.body:
In .css files, suggested colors appear in the pop-up box in duplicate. 

To reproduce:
1. In a .css stylesheet with colors specified, start typing a new color rule (e.g., `background: #`)
2. Pop-up suggesting colors lists each color twice.

Windows 10, VS Code 1.13.1
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: Debugging extensions stops when changing folder
data.body:
Debug any extension using VS Code Insiders
In the extension host window that opens up, change the folder
Observe that the debugging session in the main vs code window closes

data.title: Localized strings should be escaped in html
data.body:
https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/28335#issuecomment-307786372

We shouldn't inject localized strings into our html without escaping them or setting them with the `innerText` property.

data.title: parameter renaming is not propagated correctly
Expanding collapsed function causes text to be selected

milestone.title: Backlog

data.body:
It'll be great if you could create your own collapsed code, maybe wrapping it by and special character. For example here i have three different things going on in the same controller, i'll be really usefull to have that possibility, so the code would go from:

` //Some code`
`  /* ..... */`
`  /* ..... */`
`  /* ..... */`
`  /* ..... */`

 `//Some other code`
 `  /* ..... */`
 ` /* ..... */`

 `//Again some other code`
 ` /* ..... */`
  `/* ..... */`
  `/* ..... */`
  `/* ..... */`

to:

` //Some code`
` (collapsed code)`

` //Some other code`
` (collapsed code)`

` //Again some other code`
` (collapsed code)`

data.title: Files opened with the same name only show path when in the same group
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.14.0-insider (954193248183c7bb4d70c89898bc5337ce57fe98, 2017-06-29T05:07:31.424Z)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 16.6.0
---

Currently when you open 2 files with the same name (in the same tab group) part of the path is added to the tab so that you can tell them apart (which is great). But if you move one of those files into a new tab group (or open it in a new group -- the mechanism doesn't matter) it no longer show the disambiguation help. I don't feel the layout of the tabs should matter for determining whether or not to show the path, since it is still hard to tell which file is which in that case.

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open src/a/package.json in tab group 1
1. Open src/b/package.json in tab group 1
1. 👍  Both tabs will show part of the path

1. Open src/a/package.json in tab group 1
1. Open src/b/package.json in tab group 2
1. 🐛  Neither tab will show part of the path

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: Bug: indentation detection incorrect when a block comment appears inside an argument list
Save non-standard language modes of project files in workspace settings
data.body:
Feature suggestion:

It would be useful it the language mode for specific files could be remembered. In projects, I'd suggest saving this information in the workspace settings. (I think storing only _non-standard_ - manually changed - language modes is enough.)

For example, we sometimes have files in our projects which may have no extension or which may have an additional extension such as `.sample` at the end. Currently, when editing such files, we always have to press Ctrl+K,M and change the language mode to the right one (e.g. JSON), again and again after every time the file was closed. If the project would remember that I set the file `config.json.sample` as a JSON file last time, for example, it would save some hassle.

data.title: Make EH debugging not event order dependent
data.body:
Currently the way extension host debugging is implemented it is very much depended on event ordering and timing. We should invest in making this less fragile.

Issue where this is showing up https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/29334

data.title: Selection not updating in replace ("Find in selection" is weird)
data.body:
The "Find in Selection" in replace (Ctrl +H) is a weird hybrid of a single action, and a toggleable mode. It should either be one or the other.

The UI button and the text suggest that it should be a single action and not a mode. The fact that the selection doesn't update (in the find UI) also suggests this. However, when pressed a second time, instead of performing the same action with a different selection, it acts as if it "exited" a selection mode and returns to finding every keyword in the file. It's not very intuitive.

- VSCode Version: Code 1.12.1 (f6868fce3eeb16663840eb82123369dec6077a9b, 2017-05-04T21:26:50.689Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.14393
- Extensions: 

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|python|donjayamanne|0.6.5|
|cpptools|ms-vscode|0.11.4|
|csharp|ms-vscode|1.10.0|
|code-spell-checker|streetsidesoftware|1.1.0|;


---

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Create a test file with multiple instances of the same keyword. Ex:
```
    test1
    test2
    test3
```
2. CTRL+F to enter replace mode.
3. Enter the keyword ("test") into the "Find" box.
4. Highlight a single keyword. 
5. Click "Find in selection".
6. Select other lines with different keywords. (Notice the lack of updating)
7. Click "Find in selection" again. (Notice that instead of finding all keywords in selection, it goes back to finding all in the file).

Perhaps such a problem is already known for this case, but i not found :(
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: Improve terminal navigation
data.body:
Navigating to the right terminal for me is harder than it should be. 

I can switch to the terminal panel easily, but from there I need to get to the right terminal. I can use shortcuts for that but they are "unstable" because they depend on the sequence in which I opened my terminals.

I can use `Open View` but it's suboptimal because it's a long list. Good thing is terminals have ids, so I can use it to filter the list quickly.

I'd like to get an Open Terminal command that opens a quick pick just for terminals. It should also be available as global command from <kbd>Cmd+P</kbd>`?` as `terminal`.

data.title: Newly generated extension via yeoman erorrs in test suite on Windows
data.body:
ToolVersion
VS Code1.13.1
Node6.11.0
NPM3.10.10
Windows8.1
Git2.13.2.windows.1
I followed the instructions via: https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/extensions/example-hello-world After generating an extension project, I ran `npm install` then ran `npm test` and get the following error: ``` C:\Users\bcardarella\projects\boomer>npm test > boomer@0.0.1 test C:\Users\bcardarella\projects\boomer > node ./node_modules/vscode/bin/test ### VS Code Extension Test Run ### Current working directory: C:\Users\bcardarella\projects\boomer Downloading VS Code into "C:\Users\bcardarella\projects\boomer\.vscode-test" from: https://vscode-update.azurewebsites.net/1.13.1/win32-archive/stable Running extension tests: C:\Users\bcardarella\projects\boomer\.vscode-test\Code C:\Users\bcardarella\projects\boomer\test --extensionDevelopmentPath=C:\Users\bcardarella\projects\boomer --extensionTestsPath= C:\Users\bcardarella\projects\boomer\test Failed to execute tests: Error: spawn C:\Users\bcardarella\projects\boomer\.vscode-test\Code ENOENT Tests exited with code: -4058 npm ERR! Test failed. See above for more details. ``` I am not a regular Windows user (attempting to add Windows support to another extension) so I'm not quite sure what the problem is and how best to resolve. Considering a newly generated extension isn't working I would say something is wrong with my dev environment but its not clear to me what that would be.
